questions.prompt: Who is responsible for storage and custody of meters, endpoints, lids, and installation materials?
questions.helperText: Best practice: Assign clear custody and insurance responsibility to avoid disputes over loss, theft, or damage.
questions.notePrompt: Describe storage locations, access hours, security requirements, insurance expectations, and any constraints.
implications: Unclear custody increases risk of disputes and contingency pricing.
Contractor custody typically increases price but reduces ambiguity.
Utility custody shifts access and productivity risk to the utility.

questions.prompt: Will there be a centralized warehouse or staging location available for this project?
questions.helperText: Best practice: Defined staging improves productivity, accountability, and deployment pacing.
questions.notePrompt: Describe location(s), size/capacity, access hours, security, proximity to deployment areas, and constraints.
implications: Lack of staging clarity increases logistics risk and contingency pricing.
Regional staging can improve route efficiency but adds coordination complexity.

questions.prompt: Who is responsible for disposal, recycling, or salvage of removed materials?
options: Materials will be returned to utility inventory
questions.helperText: Best practice: Clearly define disposal responsibility to avoid regulatory exposure and post-award disputes.
questions.notePrompt: Describe material types, salvage expectations, approved recyclers, landfill restrictions, or utility policies.
implications: Unclear disposal responsibility increases compliance and cost risk.
Contractor-led disposal simplifies field operations but increases bid cost.

questions.prompt: Will lithium batteries or electronic components require special handling, transport, or recycling?
options: Yes — both lithium batteries and electronic components
questions.helperText: Best practice: Identify special handling early to comply with DOT, EPA, and state regulations.
questions.notePrompt: Note battery types, endpoint models, applicable regulations, approved recyclers, or utility policies.
implications: Special handling requirements affect crew training, transport, and certified recycler availability.
Failure to identify requirements early increases compliance and schedule risk.

questions.prompt: Who is responsible for material loss, theft, or damage while materials are in storage or transit?
questions.helperText: Best practice: Align responsibility with custody and insurance coverage to avoid disputes.
questions.notePrompt: Describe insurance requirements, custody transfer points, reporting timelines, and exceptions.
implications: Shared or unclear responsibility drives contingency pricing.

questions.prompt: Will materials be delivered in bulk or phased to align with deployment?
options: Phased delivery aligned to deployment schedule
questions.helperText: Best practice: Material delivery strategy directly affects contractor risk pricing, crew efficiency, and schedule certainty.
questions.notePrompt: Describe delivery timing, quantities, coordination responsibilities, and schedule communication.
implications: Lack of clarity on material availability increases contingency pricing.
Upfront delivery improves efficiency but increases storage and security risk.
Phased delivery requires a clearly defined and coordinated schedule to avoid inefficiency.

questions.prompt: Are there any site-specific or regulatory constraints related to material storage or disposal?
questions.helperText: Best practice: Early identification of constraints reduces compliance risk and change orders.
questions.notePrompt: Describe known regulations, permits, approved facilities, or prior issues.
implications: Undisclosed constraints increase schedule and compliance risk.
Early disclosure improves bid accuracy and reduces disputes.
